review_title: Solid Fun with a Few Tweaks
one_reviews_text:
First impressions of this game were poor, to the point that I almost didn't bother playing.  Glad that I gave it a shot, as it's quite a bit of fun with some adjustments to the settings.

Heavily recommend:
- Applying at least a 1.5x Super Sampling via Oculus Debug Tool PRIOR to launching game.  Can't adjust SS level during game, and game has HORRIBLE aliasing if SS not used.
- Force 45FPS ASW to cope with Super Sampling.
- Play game on *Easy* difficulty to prevent enemies from becoming bullet sponges.  Normally play all games on Hard difficulty, but enemies feel awful with very high health in this game.

Have some fun!

review_title: I agree: that Captain's butt is awesome
one_reviews_text: Seeking Dawn is a special game. It is an ambitious project, with a small brief initial introduction, a simple tutorial incorporated in the early stages of the game, pleasant too, a set of dialogues in English that reminds me games with a much higher budget, a good integration of the menus , some beautiful game mechanics, fun animations for weapons and tools, very simple crafting. The maps are quite linear but never give the idea of being idly conceived. The player proceed without having so many alternatives on a fixed path but can very well imagine being on a huge planet. The boundaries of the maps are plausible and well integrated into the environment. The views are varied, with huge monsters lying lazily on mountains, giant jellyfish flying in the sky, planets with rings of asteroids, etc. The graphic suffers from a sort of "graininess", as if it were poorly defined, but can be fantastic with “ultra settings. In my PC, with a GTX 1080 and 32 giga of ram this title runs smothly and is sumptuous. The music reminds maybe Mass Effect for the synth bass line, and it's simple. Does not bother. It is there, to underline the phases of action. Sometimes it is not well synchronized with what happens in the game, as if the developers expected our look to be directed towards a specific point that we may not yet have discovered. In few words this game is AWESOME. In general it seems to me that the developers have really invested many months/years of work on Seeking Dawn, and that their passion to produce an experience comparable to those of much more publicized and well-known titles can be seen in many small aspects of the work. I am satisfied with the title, I am happy that there are people capable of producing something so sumptuous in the Oculus Store. The limits that I have noticed are completely negligible. This is an example for all developers who want to sell products in the Oculus Store.

A decent sci-fi adventure that is very impressive for a Chinese (pardon my bigotry) developer. I may have to explain myself here, but so far asian developers have not impressed me (yes, I'm looking at you mortal blitz and unearthing mars 1 and 2).
So why only three stars?

The fighting is not very good. You mostly point, shoot and back away (or wait enemies out because of bad AI).
There is no melee / grenade system.
No cover mechanics (except in some cases cave walls).

These three factors actually make the combat feel a bit two dimensional, although it is in a virtual space.

I am 3-4 hours into the game and there have been no meaningful conversations with anyone, so those expecting a npc dialogue heavy rpg may want to look elsewhere.

There is not much handholding in the game, which I actually appreciate because it reinforces the cosmic Robinson Crusoe vibe.

All in all I am very impressed with how well made this game is and the sum is better than its parts.
Would not recommend it at it's full price, but if you like to explore alien worlds, then this is surely worth the price when on sale.

I Really hope this talented developer makes an new VR game soon, because it would probably be spectacular :)

The level design is really good.  It's very impressive in some places.  It looks like they were influenced by Mass Effect, Halo, maybe Destiny.

review_title: Fun, but Deceitful Trailer & Many Issues
one_reviews_text:
I'm writing this review in April of 2019. First off, I will say that Seeking Dawn is one of the most fun experiences I've had in VR to date. That is, when it played well. The environments are amazing and immersive, I truly felt like I was on an alien planet. The guns are actually all very unique and offer a fun twist on traditional "point-and-shoot" VR games. The boss fights are where this game shines, especially the last two boss fights. 

Still, this game has many problems. First off, the trailer... yea, that is a complete lie. After finishng the game and rewatching the trailer, I was stunned. The trailer is so unlike the game itself that it's honestly insulting. Many of the environments and I think even some enemies from the trailer are not even in the game... what the heck? That's so not cool. It also sucks that the game only includes NPC's in the very beginning. There was so much potential to add NPS'c throughout the game that was completely wasted. The game is also very fidgety, from the quick select menu being way to close to your body, to the harvesting system making the frame rate drop for a few seconds. Enemies are also extreme bullet sponges, making the difficulty feel artificial and frustrating. 

Overall, I suggest looking up actual gameplay of the game, not the deceitful trailer. If your willing to deal with the semi-common occurance of minor bugs and immersion breaking frame rate drops, there is a great VR experience here; however, this game is overall another example of the potential of VR not fully realized.

review_title: Accept the bugs and save often
one_reviews_text:
To get the most enjoyment out of this game, adapt to the programming bugs and save often. The worst bug I have encountered is when I die or 'quit without saving' I will lose a weapon or other inventory. Do it a few times in a row and my entire inventory will be gone, including ammo and teleport gun, stranding me and putting me basically at the begining of the game, equipment wise. Avoid this by quitting the app via the Oculus button and restart to re-open a saved game. If you attempt to re-open a previous save point via 'quit without saving' the autosave simply locks you into any inventory deletions, erasing whatever number of hours of advancing done since the last 'good' save point. So manually save often.

It is tough to find a balance between graphics turned up enough to see above an N64 era game (ok, maybe Sega Saturn), and having a normal frame rate while running or during combat with 2 or more enemies. I have read about issues since the last update, but now I see what they mean - stuff is turned way down, but frame rate is still low. review_title: Beware of patch 2.0! - How to fix it ;-)
one_reviews_text:
First of all after patching to 2.0 I experienced severe image ghosting and I thought that the patch was to blame - now I'm not so sure. At least after updating from Oculus v. 1.32 to v. 1.33 I was able to play the game with no image ghosting, and I was able to use super sampling (pixel density) 1.6 - all settings maxed, but without antialiasing (could turn antialiasing on without problems, but it didn't do much using ss 1.6, so I turned it off). Maybe the Oculus Update 1.32 caused the severe image ghosting, not the Seeking Dawn 2.0 patch... Also note that using Forceware 417.35 may be quite important and part of solution to eliminate any image ghosting in Seeking Dawn. Thus in case of image ghosting, try to use the latest drivers for your video card. 
Patch 2.0 seems to include heavily downscaled  resolution - probably the reason why 2.0 performs so much better than before, but it looks horribly pixelated - at least until pixel density is set to at least 1.4. But you can only set pixel density to 1.2 in-game, so how to get 1.4 and beyond? The pixel density value in-game is multiplied with the Oculus Tray Tool value - that's how I got ss 1.6, but you need to do the math ;-)
Also when the game works, Seeking Dawn not only shines but outshines all other VR games I can think of, even Lone Echo - although mostly when it comes to the gameplay and graphics (the story in Lone Echo is still second to none).
Seeking Dawn still has long loading times and could use further polishing, but it's the most awesome world, it truly feels like being on an alien planet. Sometimes I don't even care about playing the game - I just like to be present in the world - to walk around and enjoy the scenery - it's that good.

The game is too short, I got to the final boss around what I expected to be the halfway point. There are essentially 3 distinct tiers of weapons, each one 4-6 times more powerful than the last. This makes the pacing of the game very awkward as you can't quite afford the equipment for the next area, so its insanely hard, you get that last piece you need, then it is way too easy.

Overall, its an enjoyable game thats too short, too buggy, and poorly balanced.

Second update:

There are significant lag issues when playing online so that you take damage from a melee enemy who is not close to you. There is also significant lag every time you mine a resource and the resources themselves spawn. I have been kicked out a few times due to network issues, only to lose significant progress because the game didn't auto save my character. As in, I lost the guns I had bought and the resources I mined. The game itself is pretty and plays fairly well, but these are some pretty bad issues. Only not putting four stars because of the initial difficulty I had with the game.

Original post below.

Terrible menus, (accidentally exiting the game when trying to set options), can't get through the tutorial, stuck at gate that won't open. Eventually got the gate to open after leaving and reentering the game several times. Eating is much harder than it should be. At first, I couldn't get my character to eat anything, occasionally, it would play the eating sound without eating. Eventually, I learned I had to eat out of my palm. The first real mission requires better weapons than you start with, but you won't have enough material to make those weapons before you start, and the fast travel item isn't given to the user until after that mission.

This game isn't stable, it isn't polished, and it isn't finished.

This game is quite simply one of the best VR experiences and graphically right up there with lone echo. It almost looks like the sort of game we would be expecting to play in the next gen, as the current blurry headsets really cannot do it justice.  I am also really enjoying the gameplay loop. Is it perfect? Graphically pretty much -
a truely immersive realisation of an alien world, both beautiful and unsettling at the same time. Sound is fantastic (except the 'monsters are coming' soundtrack kicks in at times for no apparent reason). Voice and script is its weak spot, at times this aspect can be quite dreadful. Gameplay - well I am really enjoying it - at the same time I keep thinking how wonderful it would be if they did this, or did that. 
So conclusions - a game that is simply one of the best graphically, but falling down with the script and voice 'talent'. Also let down by the perhaps over-ambitious gameplay that shows genuine potential, but does not manage to totally realize that potential. (I am hoping that this sells well enough for the devopers to hang in there and slowly work on this aspect).

My conclusion is this - something of a flawed masterpiece - but enough fragments of a masterpiece to be well worth you time and money. Oculus should grab the talent on this team, nurture it, throw some cash at them, hire some script writers and voice actors -  to allow them to produce the AAA game we are all waiting for. 

Note on performance - I had a horrible experience with screen tearing and framerate when I first booted it up - to the point that I was going to have to (reluctantly) return it. But I rebooted my system (I7/GTX1060) and it ran like a dream on medium settings. No problems since. 

To all those negative comments both here and on Reddit - man, I do not get it. I can only assume that the 'grumpy uncles' from the world of pancake gaming are sponsoring this as part of strategy to sabotage VR. 
Do you guys actually want VR to succeed?

This is the first game that my system cant smoothly run maxxed out and I dont believe it has ANYTHING to do with my hardware as many others have complained about graphical bugs/ stuttering and most frustrating are the random black screen flashes that totally break the immersion of VR and often times causes you to get killed.  The game has potential and it will remind you of Halo mixed with Mass effect. The cinematic intro when you begin a new game is hands down the most gorgeous, graphically beautiful thing I've seen in VR.

So I've been playing for this past week...
This game is beautiful for one. I've never been one to care for the graphics much as long as gameplay and mechanics are comprehensive but the work put into this game is immense. I'll leave it at that.
You can make a game, save it, then reload your character (not your base setup) joining another players' world. If you get items and invest in their world, you can save it as your own and still keep your own mission progress for if you reload later. You can play with a group of 4 people total. I like to go back and help new players and watch them get excited and spooked over cool parts of this game, and kindof re-experience it. If i could give 4 1/2 stars I would. I get connection issues that kick everyone from the game when someone joins at times, or else it would be 5 stars.

P.S. (To #devs) 
Also, I've gotten all weapons besides one and it would be nice if any of these could have secondary fire as well (besides the shield). Also, when using climbing features while holding the shield you deploy the force field, since that's the secondary fire. Not sure if you want to modify that. And the venom spitter weapon, while neat in functionality shoots so slowly and awkwardly I feel that this is one that needs a secondary fire for me to want to use it. The only time I use it is when I don't want to do too much work when playing early missions with newbies. Thanks for your hard work!

Maybe wait on this one.

There has been plenty of times while exploring ive just died for no reason. Some of them im guessing it is out of bounds issues but if thats the case. Shouldn't out of bounds be out of bounds?! I shouldnt be able to just walk out and die. 
Overall even with these complaints its still an awesome game and i hope more is added to it. If these glitches were fixed it would easily be a 5/5 rating. Not being able to complete the game cause the final boss makes all your vision black doesn't cut it.
